newsitem.title: ROMANIA: Belgium wants Romania among first five for NATO-PM.
newsitem.headline: Belgium wants Romania among first five for NATO-PM.

text.p: Belgian Prime Minister Jean-Luc Dehaene said on Thursday NATO's first eastward expansion should take in five, rather than three, former East bloc states, including Romania.

"Referring to NATO's enlargement, Belgium believes that this process should be more comprehensive and aim not at three, but five countries, including Romania," a Romanian government statement quoted him as saying.
Dehaene made the remarks during talks with Romanian Prime Minister Victor Ciorbea at the start of a four-day visit.
Romania and the ex-Yugoslav Republic of Slovenia have been tipped as longshots for first-wave admission, with Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic seen as near-likely entrants.
Belgium added to political support which Romania has won so far from France, Italy and other members of NATO's southern flank, as well as from Canada.
Bucharest is wooing the United States and Britain, which have so far remained lukewarm to the Balkan country's bid. Germany has offered understanding but little concrete support.
Dehaene praised a post-communist treaty which Romania and ex-Soviet Ukraine initialled last week, ending World War Two issues over borders and minorities between the two neighbours.
He said the treaty with Kiev, which Romanian President Emil Constantinescu is expected to sign with his Ukrainian counterpart Leonid Kuchma, "is an important trump card for Romania".
